Unclaimed rewards will be discarded.
Total Missions do not have expiration dates.

The Present Box is where you can collect your presents.
There are 2 tabs for different types of Presents.
- Standard All items are stored here. - Social Social Pt. earned through greeting friends and being called in for backup in battle are stored here along with bits given to you by supporting DigiGuild members.
The dates for items that have been acquired are recorded and can be seen later. *Records will be deleted after a certain period of time.
The Present Box contains Login Bonuses, Presents from management, Tutorial Rewards, Event and Campaign Presents, and Social Points from social encounters.

Items in the Present Box have expiration dates.
Items that have not been claimed by their expiration date will be discarded, so keep an eye on your Present Box.
Expiration dates vary depending on the item.

A Tamer can choose one of their Digimon to be their Partner Digimon. The Digimon you select will have the word "Partner" appear on its icon.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/partner_1[/img] A Partner plays a unique role, and shows up as an icon on the Tamer's Profile screen. Bringing your Partner on a Quest lets you use their Special during battle.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/partner_2[/img] A Partner's Bond increases faster than other Digimon. Even if your Partner isn't in a battle, using its Special increases its Bond Points.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/partner_3[/img] Your Partner can be called on by other Tamers as Backup.

Login Bonuses can be acquired by playing the game daily. You can claim a reward once a day. One day in the game is defined as [datetime_hour]00:00[/datetime_hour] to [datetime_hour]23:59[/datetime_hour] of the next day.
Special Login Bonuses may be awarded during events along with the regular Login Bonuses.

Rewards vary depending on the type of Login Bonus.
These items can be claimed in the Present Box.

Generally, there is no expiration date for Login Bonuses. Any reward not claimed on a given day is carried over to the next day. For example, claiming the Login Bonus for the first day means that the Login Bonus for the second day will be available the next time the app is opened, even if several days pass.
Login Bonuses linked to limited-time events expire when the event ends. Objectives differ among events, and should be checked at the beginning of the event.

A function that saves current game data so that it may be transferred to another device.
Identification is required for data transfer to prevent identity theft.
Tap Menu in the top-right of your DigiTown, then Account Transfer to transfer your data.

ID Authentication verifies your identity using social media accounts, such as Twitter. If you do not have any social media accounts, please register a new account or use ID/Password instead.
Only one account in the app can be backed up using Transfer with ID Authentication. Once an ID has been used for backup, it cannot be used to back up other accounts unless you remove it from the backup settings.

Each user is provided with a unique ID (visible on Profile or Friends screens).
You can transfer your account using this ID and a password consisting of letters and numbers. Please refrain from taking screenshots, sending messages, or writing notes that include your password.

You can delete temporary files with the Clear Cache function. Old data can hinder your game experience. Clear Cache may remedy such situations.
Tap Clear Cache found under Transfer/Support at the Title screen.

Scene Select lets you browse scenes that play during Quests in the Story. You can also view the opening movie, Digivolution scenes and more.
Watching a scene once records it in the Scene Select section.
Scene Select can be accessed by tapping the Menu button at the top-right of the DigiTown screen, then Scene Select.
*Rankings will be displayed after all results have been totaled. *Rankings of events you did not participate in or did not rank in will not be displayed.

Challenges are special events held for a limited time. Earn rewards by successfully completing requests from other Digimon. Complete all requests to earn a special Completion Reward.
Tap the Challenges icon in the top-right of your DigiTown to see the Challenges screen.
Challenges with time limits will end when the designated period is over. After fulfilling the required conditions, you must claim your reward within this period. Some Challenges end as soon as you receive all of the rewards. Completed Challenges automatically disappear from the list.

You can choose your Partner in DigiTown.
Tap Team and go to Partner Selection. Pick a Digimon you would like as your Partner on the selection screen.
Play through the Main Story to unlock Partner Selection.

Digimon that appear in your DigiTown screen can roam around freely.
From this screen, items can be given to Digimon to improve their Mood and Bond.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/care_1[/img] You can send up to 7 Digimon other than your Partner to the Playground.

DigiCare settings can be accessed through your DigiTown screen.
Tap the Team icon, then DigiCare. A Digimon selection screen will be displayed, where you can choose which Digimon to DigiCare.
Play through the Main Story to unlock the DigiCare function.

There is a limit to the number of Digimon you can acquire as companions. You can use DigiRubies to increase this limit.
In DigiTown, tap the Train icon, then go to Digimon List. From there, you can expand your Digimon limit with the + symbol next to the number at the top-right of your screen. You can do this from other screens as well.

Releasing a Digimon is a function to part ways with your Digimon Friend. A Digimon that has been released will be gone forever.
When you release a Digimon, you'll receive DigiOrbs in return. The amount of DigiOrbs received will vary for each Digimon.

The Tamer Level indicates how strong a Tamer is. Your Player stamina and maximum friend limit increases as your Tamer Level increases.
Tamers can level up by completing Quests (Story, Dimensional Vortex, Underworld).

Tap the Team icon at DigiTown, then go to Release. From the screen that appears, you can select the Digimon you would like to release. You cannot release your Partner Digimon, or Digimon in your Team.
Herissmon is a special character in Digimon ReArise and cannot be released. You also cannot release In-Training I and In-Training II Digimon or DigiEggs.

The Lock function prevents you from accidentally releasing one of your Digimon. A locked Digimon cannot be chosen on the Release screen, nor can they be used as materials for upgrading Skills.
Locking a Digimon is simple and easy: Just tap and hold a Digimon's icon to bring up the Digimon Status screen. Press the Lock button next to the Digimon's name to lock it, and again to unlock it.

Training refers to all functions related to a Digimon's growth, including Upgrades, Digivolution, and equipping Plugins.
• Upgrade: 　Level up your Digimon. • Workout / Awakening: 　Train your Digimon, or awaken them to increase their level cap. • Digivolve: 　Evolve your Digimon. • Skill Upgrade: 　Raise a Digimon's Skill Level. • Ascend: 　Boost a Supercharged Digimon's Ascension Stage. • Inherit: 　Change a Digimon with a normal Personality into one with a Supercharged Personality by making it inherit 　from a Supercharged Digimon. • Equip Plugins: 　Equip a Digimon with Plugins. • Plugin Upgrade/Evolve: 　Synthesize Plugins to enhance their effects. • Plugins: 　View details on the Plugins you own. • Sell Plugins: 　Sell Plugins for bit and make space in your inventory. • Digimon List: 　View details on the Digimon you own. • Release: 　Release a Digimon and make space in your inventory.

Upgrading enables you to level up your Digimon using bit. The amount of bit consumed depends on the Digimon's Level and Stage.
Leveling up a Digimon through Upgrade increases their stats, making them more capable of taking on more difficult Quests.

In DigiTown, tap the Train icon, then Upgrade, and select Digimon you would like to strengthen.
Tap and hold the Upgrade button to spend bit. Letting go of the button finishes Upgrading your Digimon.
The bit needed for Upgrading can be obtained from the Story. You can also get it from Dimensional Vortexes or as Mission Rewards.

Use Workout Chips to train and strengthen your Digimon. Workouts consist of 6 exercises, each of which requires a certain type of Chip.
Workouts increase a Digimon's stats. The type of Chip consumed differs according to the Digimon's Personality and Stage.
Even if you don't have enough Workout Chips, the materials required to synthesize the required Workout Chips (Workout Data and Workout Fragments) can be used to train instead.

In DigiTown, tap the Train icon, then go to Workout/Awakening, and select the Digimon you would like to train.
The bit needed for workouts can be acquired from the Story. You can also get it from Dimensional Vortexes or as Mission Rewards.

Workout Chips are items needed to train your Digimon. There are 3 types altogether:
- Workout Chips - Workout Data - Workout Fragments
Workout Chips are the only ones that can be used when putting your Digimon through workouts. Workout Data and Fragments are components of Chips, and can be assembled to form Chips.
Workout Chips can be found during the Story, or crafted in Chip Synthesis. You can attain them in the Dimensional Vortex as well.

Workout Chips can be created by combining Workout Data with Workout Fragments. Some Chips can only be attained through this process.
Tap the Train icon and go to Workout / Awakening. Choose an exercise, and select Get Workout Chip. If you have the required materials, then you will be able to use Workout Chip Synthesis. If you lack the required materials, it will show you the Quests where you can find them.

You can awaken your Digimon once you've cleared all six workout exercises, increasing their stats and level cap.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/training_3[/img] Awakening consumes bit, the amount of which varies depending on the Stage of your Digimon.
Bit is used to upgrade Digimon, prompt Digivolution, undergo Workouts, and more. These can be acquired as Login Bonuses, and by completing Quests and Missions.

In DigiTown, tap the Train icon, then go to Workout/Awakening, and select the Digimon you would like to Awaken.
You can Awaken your Digimon after fulfilling the following conditions: - Complete all 6 workout exercises - Raise the Digimon to the required (maximum) level
The bit needed to Awaken Digimon can be acquired from the Story. You can also get it from Dimensional Vortexes or as Mission Rewards.

Digivolution uses DGV-Codes and bit to transform Digimon into stronger stages. The number of DGV-Codes and bit needed for Digivolution varies depending on a Digimon's Stage.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/evolution_3[/img] Digivolving your Digimon boosts their stats immensely, and raises the caps on their Level and Bond. The Digimon's name, appearance, and Skills change as well.
Each Digimon in Digimon ReArise only has a single Digivolution branch. There are no conditions that will unlock other Digivolution branches for your Digimon.

In DigiTown, tap the Train icon then go to Digivolve and select the Digimon you would like to Digivolve.
You can Digivolve your Digimon after fulfilling the following conditions: - Raise your Digimon to max Level - Max out your Bond with Digimon - Own the required number of DGV-Codes - Have the required amount of bit
You can acquire bit from Story missions and more. DGV-Codes can be obtained from the shop or from Clash Battle rewards. The amount of DGV-Codes and bit required depends on the Digimon's Stage and Attribute.

DGV-Codes are items required for a Digimon to Digivolve. There are DGV-Codes for each type of Attribute—Fire, Water, Plant, Earth, Wind, Electric, Holy, Dark, Void—all of which have classifications: Easy, Normal or Hard. The type and number of DGV-Codes needed will depend on your Digimon's current Stage.
There are also special DGV-Codes that do not belong to any type of Attribute. Some Digimon even require a DGV-Code just for them.
You can obtain DGV-Codes from the Shop or Clash Battles.

Digimon have Skills that can be used during battle. Skill Levels show how far a skill has been enhanced. There are four types of Skills: Main, Sub, Passive, and EX.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/skilllevelup_1[/img] When Digimon fuse together or when Skill Stones are used, their Skill Level increases, as does the effect of their Main, Sub, and EX Skills. Skill Level maxes out at level 15. Passive Skill effects do not change even if Skill Levels increase.
*Check the Combining Digimon section for more information about Digimon fusion.

Tap Train, then Skill Upgrade from DigiTown and select the base Digimon you want to level up.
Select the Digimon you want to combine with the base Digimon. When you combine the Digimon together, your Skill Level will increase. Digimon used for Skill Upgrade will disappear.
You can acquire Digimon from DigiEggs or Summons. *Check the Combining Digimon section for more information.
You can also use Skill Stones in place of Digimon. Skills for Supercharged Digimon can only be upgraded with Skill Stones. *Check the Skill Stone section for more information.

Digimon that can be used as Material for Skill Upgrade must have the same Personality and same Digivolution Chain as the base Digimon.
Even if you have two Agumon, you cannot Combine them if they have different Digivolution Chains. You can check Digimon's Digivolution Chain on its Details screen.
The Skill Level of Supercharged Digimon can only be raised with Skill Stones.

Plugins are disks (equipment) inscribed with data used to further draw out a Digimon's potential.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/plugin_2[/img]
Place Plugins in your equipment slots to equip them, raising your Digimon's stats and sometimes providing special effects. Each Digimon has a maximum of 6 equipment slots—two each for ATK, DEF and SPE. Not all equipment slots can be used at first, they will gradually unlock as a Digimon Digivolves. All of a Digimon's slots are unlocked when their Bond reaches the maximum of 99. You can unequip Plugins anytime you want.
Plugins have the following stats: - Rarity: Shows how common the Plugin is. The higher the rarity, the more amazing the Plugin. - Grade: Shows how powerful the Plugin is. The higher the Grade, the more powerful the Plugin. - Plugin Lv: The level to which the Plugin has been boosted. Boosting a Plugin to its max will increase its Grade by one.

In DigiTown, tap the Train icon, then go to Equip Plugin and select the Digimon to which you want to equip a Plugin.
You can unequip Plugins anytime you want.
Plugins can be acquired in Quests or from Plugin Summons.

DigiRubies are a special in-game currency. Using them enables you to do the following:
- Recover depleted stamina. - Continue battles after a defeat. - Increase maximum number of Digimon. - Increase maximum number of Plugins. - Increase maximum number of Decorations. - Use Digimon Summons or Plugin Summons. - Buy items from the Shop.
DigiRubies can be bought from the Shop.

Plugin Upgrade is to increase the Plugin Lv. by using Plugins and bit. The amount of Material Plugins and bit needed depends on the Grade of the Base Plugin and number of times boosted.
Plugin Lv. starts from 0, and you can boost it up to +5.
If Plugins with the same category (ATK, DEF, or SPE) as the Base Plugin are used, it will be easier to raise its Plugin Lv.
Increasing Plugin Lv. will modify the Plugin's stats, which make your Digimon stronger.
- "Recommended" Function When upgrading Plugins, you can automatically select Plugins based on the following criteria: - Same category as the selected Plugin - Prioritize Plugins with high Upgrade Pt. - No Personality restrictions - Rarity 1 - Grade 1 (ATK, DEF) - Grade 3 (SPE) - Plugin Lv. 0 - Unequipped - Unlocked

Plugin Evolve consumes bit to enhance the Grade of the Plugin by one level. The amount of bit needed depends on the current Grade of the Plugin you are trying to upgrade.
Plugin Evolution is possible if the following conditions are met: - Plugin Lv. is at its highest - Have the required amount of bit
Stats will be greatly modified when a Plugin's grade is raised.
The Plugin Lv. will return to 0 after its Grade is raised. Once a Plugin reaches the highest Grade, it cannot be further evolved.

A Plugin that increases the ATK (PWR/TEC) of a Digimon.
There are 4 types: Plugins that can be equipped by any Digimon; Plugins that can only be equipped by Digimon with a certain Personality; Plugins that grant bonus effects to specific Digimon; and Plugins that can only be equipped by specified Digimon.

A Plugin that increases the DEF of a Digimon.
There are 4 types: Plugins that can be equipped by any Digimon; Plugins that can only be equipped by Digimon with a certain Personality; Plugins that grant bonus effects to specific Digimon; and Plugins that can only be equipped by specified Digimon.

A Plugin that grants additional abilities to a Digimon and improves its existing effects.
There are 4 types: Plugins that can be equipped by any Digimon; Plugins that can only be equipped by Digimon with a certain Personality; Plugins that grant bonus effects to specific Digimon; and Plugins that can only be equipped by specified Digimon.

In the Sell Plugins menu, you can sell Plugins that you no longer need.
In DigiTown, tap the Train icon, then Sell Plugins, and select Plugins you want to sell.
You can get bit in exchange for selling Plugins. The amount of bit obtained depends on the Plugins. Plugins that have been sold are gone forever.
- "Recommended" Function When selling Plugins, you can automatically select Plugins based on the following criteria: - Rarity 1 - Grade 1 (ATK, DEF) - Grade 3 (SPE) - No Personality Restrictions - Plugin Lv. 0 - Unequipped - Unlocked

There is a limit to the number of Plugins you can have. You can use DigiRubies to increase this limit.
In DigiTown, tap the Train icon, then go to Plugin List and tap the + symbol next to the number at the top-right of your screen, indicating how many Plugins you have. You can do this from other screens as well.

Some Plugins activate a hidden ability when equipped to certain Digimon.
The characters "SP" will appear on any Plugins that have such a special effect. *Digimon applicable as a target Digimon are those that match the Personality and Digimon name included in the Plugin's name. Plugins that modify attack power (PWR/TEC) cannot be set on Digimon whose attack type does not match. *BON Plugins can be set to any Digimon with a matching Personality, but only the Plugin's Normal stats will be applied. *BON Plugins for Supercharged Digimon can be set to any Digimon as long as they have the same Personality type (for example, Super Brave and Brave), but only the Plugin's Normal stats will be applied. *Up to 2 Attack, Defense, or Special BON Plugins can be set to a single Digimon.

In Care Mode, you can give Care Items to your Digimon to improve their Mood and increase their Bond.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/training_1[/img] Feeding them a certain amount of Care Items will render your Digimon full and satisfied. They will stop accepting Care Items for a set period.

Select a Digimon while you're in DigiTown. Drag and drop a Care Item from the panel that appears at the bottom-right of the screen.
Care Items can be found in Quests. They can also be acquired from the Shop, DigiWalk feature and more.
You can Care for your Battle Team by tapping on the "Care for All" button on the Gear Up screen before the start of each battle. You can Care for the entire team all at once, using only as many Care Items as is necessary to reach the maximum Mood level. *If you do not have enough Care Items, Mood will be increased accordingly based on the Care Items consumed.

Stamina is necessary for Tamers to go on Quests. You can recover 1 Stamina every 3 minutes. You can also restore Stamina by using recovery drinks or by spending DigiRubies or Social Points.
Boosting maximum Stamina in the following circumstances will also restore your stamina: - Increasing your Tamer Level. - Using DigiRubies. - Using a Stamina Drink to restore stamina. - Receiving Support from a DigiGuild.

Requests refer to Digimon wanting certain Care Items.
These items appear in a speech bubble above the Digimon.
Giving a Digimon the Care Item it requests greatly amplifies the item's effect.

An exclusive item that can be used in place of a Digimon when combining.
Unlike combining with a Digimon, the success rate varies depending on the Skill Stone used.
The Skill Stone and bit used will be lost regardless of its success.

DigiOrbs are crystallized items of a Digimon's memories and relationships.
They are mainly acquired by releasing a Digimon.
You can exchange them for a variety of items at the Shop.

Step-Up Summons are Summons whose drop rates and bonuses change depending on how many times you use them. Steps will be taken each time Summons are used. After reaching a certain number of Steps, some Summons will return your Steps to 0 or continue to increase them. Available Digimon vary depending on the Summon; you can check what is available and their drop rate by viewing Summon Rates.
A bonus granting you a guaranteed Digimon or Plugin can be obtained based on your number of Steps or once you have reached a certain number of Steps.

There are certain Plugins that can only be set to specified Digimon.
You will be unable to set those Plugins to any other Digimon.
These Plugins will be marked as "Exclusive."
*Digimon applicable as a target Digimon are those that match the Personality and Digimon name included in the Plugin's name. Plugins that modify attack power (PWR/TEC) cannot be set on Digimon whose attack type does not match.
*Up to 2 Attack, Defense, or Special Unique Plugins can be set to a single Digimon.

By using the required Hero Codes, Valiant Codes, Personality Emblems, Super DGV-Codes, and Unique DGV-Codes, a Digimon's level cap may be raised to 100 and above.
The type and number of items required for Super Awakening differs according to the Digimon's Personality and Stage.

In DigiTown, tap the Train icon, then go to Workout/Awakening, and select the Digimon you would like to Super Awaken.
You can Super Awaken your Digimon after fulfilling the following condition: - Raise the Digimon to level 99

A Hero Code is an item required to Super Awaken Digimon.  
Hero Codes can be obtained as a reward in the Underworld Dungeon or as a Season Reward (Rank S) in the Battle Park.

A Valiant Code is an item required to Super Awaken Digimon.
Valiant Codes can be obtained as a Clash Battle reward.

A Personality Emblem is an item required to Super Awaken Digimon. There are 5 in all: Brave/Super Brave Emblem, Calm/Super Calm Emblem, Deft/Super Deft Emblem, Tenacious/Super Tenacious Emblem, and Devoted/Super Devoted Emblem.
Personality Emblems can be obtained as a reward in the Underworld Dungeon.

Raging Raid Battle! is a battle available for a limited period of time where you team up with other Tamers to take on a powerful foe.
Raging Raid Battle! Rules Team up with your Partner Digimon and other Tamers' Partner Digimon to fight battles. All Tamers that participate and win the battle within the time limit will get Raid rewards! Specials cannot be used during battle.
There are multiple difficulty levels. Clearing one level will unlock the next. Once you have cleared a difficulty level, you cannot select it again. However, the levels can be restarted from easy once a day at a predetermined time.
Team Teams are composed of your Partner Digimon and five other Partner Digimon. Your team can have Digimon of the same Personality and Digivolution Chain.
Rewards Each difficulty level allows you to earn different rewards. Furthermore, the rewards will be sent to the befriended Tamer's Present Box.

Decorations are items that you can use to furnish DigiTown.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/deco_2[/img] The News board and Incubator that you start off with cannot be moved, but you can place other Decorations around the town however you like.
Some Decorations can affect the behavior of Digimon within their vicinity. Try playing around with Decorations when you first buy them.

There is a special Plugin that grants the holder effects that are usually limited to Digimon Passive Skills. Setting such a Plugin to a Digimon adds an additional Passive Effect.
Plugins with a Passive Effect will have a Passive Skill icon displayed in its stats. The Passive Effect of a Plugin functions in essentially the same way as a Digimon's Passive Skill. Passive Skill/Effects do not stack. In a case where there are two of the same Passive Skill/Effect, the one with the higher effect will take precedence. Passive Effects are permanent rather than turn-based.
You can check the Passive Effect of a Plugin by checking the Digimon Stats screen or Equip Plugin screen.

Ascension is a menu option that only applies to Digimon with Supercharged Personalities. It raises a Digimon's Stats, max skill level, and Ascension Stage. There are a maximum of 4 Ascension Stages.
Ascension consumes bit.

In DigiTown, tap the Train icon then go to Ascend and select the Digimon you would like to Ascend. You can Ascend your Digimon after fulfilling the following conditions: • You must have multiple Digimon of the same Chain with Supercharged Personalities. • Digimon must be level 99 or above.
Digimon used for Ascension material will be lost. The level, bond, skill level, and Ascension Stage is based on the values of the Base Digimon. The bit needed for Ascension can be obtained from the story. They can also be obtained from Dimensional Vortexes or as Mission Rewards.

Inheritance allows you to use Digimon with Supercharged Personality as combining material to pass abilities on to Digimon with normal personalities. Inheritance will result in a higher level, bond, and skill level, turning your Digimon into one with a Supercharged Personality.
Inheritance consumes bit.

In DigiTown, tap the Train icon then go to Inherit and select the Digimon you would like to Inherit.
You can perform Inherit on your Digimon after fulfilling the following conditions: • You must have at least one Digimon with a normal Personality and one Digimon with a Supercharged Personality. • Digimon must be level 99 or above. • The Digimon with a normal personality receiving the Inheritance
must have a level, skill level or bond higher than that of the Digimon with a Supercharged Personality.
Digimon used for Inheritance material will be lost. The bit needed for Inheritance can be obtained from the story. They can also be obtained from Dimensional Vortexes or as Mission Rewards.

A Supercharged Personality is a personality that is above normal personalities. There are five Supercharged Personalities in total: Super Brave, Super Calm, Super Deft, Super Tenacious, and Super Devoted.
Supercharged Personalities have the following features: • Digimon with Supercharged Personalities will be able to Ascend. You can check the Ascension Stages by looking at the number on the right side of the Digimon icon. • Once a Digimon has achieved its final Digivolution, the EX Skill will be unlocked as its 3rd skill. • An aura that matches the Digimon's personality color will appear. The more you progress through the Ascension Stages, the stronger the aura gets. • Digimon will be able to pass on their unique abilities via Inheritance.
Ascension This is a feature that strengthens Digimon with Supercharged Personalities. For more information about Ascension, please refer to the "Ascension" section in Help.
Inheritance Inheritance is a feature that allows you to combine a Digimon with a normal personality with one of a higher personality level to create a Digimon with Supercharged Personality. For more information about Inheritance, please refer to the "Inheritance" section in Help.

Each personality has its advantages and disadvantages in battle.
Brave/Super Brave is strong against Deft/Super Deft, Deft/Super Deft is strong against Calm/Super Calm, and Calm/Super Calm is strong against Brave/Super Brave, making this a three-way deadlock.
This will affect the damage dealt and received to each of these Personalities.
Tenacious/Super Tenacious and Devoted/Super Devoted are the opposite of each other, making them a two-way deadlock.
This will affect the damage dealt to each of these Personalities.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/sukumi_1[/img]

Abilities unique to a single Digimon. These can only be learned in the last stage of Digivolution. These are mainly attack-type Skills, some of which inflict status abnormalities on opponents.
Using a Main Skill makes it unavailable for a set period of time (the Cooldown phase). It has a very long Cooldown Time compared to other skills.
Upgrade a Main Skill's Skill Level to make it more powerful.

DigiDiamonds are an item that can be exchanged for a Digimon. They can be obtained by using Summons. DigiDiamonds can be exchanged at the DigiDiamond Exchange inside the Shop.
*They are not available in all Summons, but are only available in Summons that use DigiRubies. Furthermore, 1x Summons are not applicable, and conditions vary for each Summon.

Decorations that haven't been placed in your DigiTown are stored in Storage.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/deco_1[/img] To place a Decoration, tap the Deco button in DigiTown to enter Edit Decorations mode. A panel will appear with all of your Decorations currently in storage. Just drag and drop a Decoration into DigiTown to place it.
Four buttons appear when placing Furnishings: - Storage: Cancel placement and move Decoration back into Storage. - Cancel: Redo Decoration placement. - Rotate: Rotate a Decoration 90 degrees. - Confirm: Confirm placement for Decoration. Move Decorations by dragging them. Tapping and holding a Decoration in DigiTown sends you into Edit Decorations mode.

Tap the Deco button in DigiTown to enter Edit Decorations mode.
To remove a Decoration, tap it then tap the Storage button.

Tap the Deco button in DigiTown to enter Edit Decoration mode. Tap the Sell button on the top-right of the screen to go to the Sell screen, then select the Decoration you'd like to sell.
When a Decoration is sold, you will get bit in return. The amount of bit received depends on the Furnishing. Decorations that have been sold are gone forever.

There is a limit to the number of Decorations you can acquire—100 in the beginning. You can spend DigiRubies to increase this limit.
In DigiTown, tap the Deco icon, then go to Edit Decoration mode and press the + symbol next to the number at the top-right of your screen. You can increase your limit up to 300 Decorations.

Guest Digimon are Partner Digimon of other Tamers that can come to hang out in your DigiTown. They have a brown circle at their feet, so you can distinguish them from your own Digimon.
Guest Digimon leave after a set period of time, but others will appear in their place.

The Greet Digimon function allows you to communicate with Guest Digimon in your DigiTown.
Tap the Greet button that appears when you select the Guest Digimon to interact with them.
Greeting Guest Digimon gives you Social Points.

DigiEggs are Digimon Eggs.
Incubating them will give birth to a In-Training I or In-Training II Digimon, but you usually don't know what Digimon will come out until you hatch it.

The Incubator is a device used to hatch DigiEggs.
There are two in the center of DigiTown; the Incubator on the left can be used from the beginning.
The Incubator on the right is a special Incubator made available when you join a DigiGuild.

Digimon is an abbreviation for Digital Monsters.
Digimon were originally computer viruses with artificial intelligence that spread across the world. They took on shapes and gained personalities while exploring the internet, evolving into digital lifeforms. Digimon are the only lifeforms in the Digital World, and come in many different species.

Selecting an Incubator in DigiTown makes a panel appear containing your DigiEggs. Drag and drop one of your DigiEggs into the Incubator to start the hatching process.
You cannot take out the DigiEgg once the Incubator is activated, and you cannot place another DigiEgg into the Incubator until the Digimon matures to Rookie.
The Incubator is powered by bit, and must be injected into the device to use it. The amount of bit required each time and the number of times you need to repeat this process depends on the DigiEgg.

When the DigiEgg hatches, an In-Training I Digimon will be born. This Digimon walks around your DigiTown like any other Digimon. Continuing to care for this Digimon causes it to Digivolve to the In-Training II Stage.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/childhood_1[/img] In-Training I and In-Training II Digimon cannot fight. To bring Digimon along on Quests, it must be at the Rookie Stage or higher.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/childhood_2[/img]

Select an In-Training I Digimon in DigiTown to check its Digivolution Chain, and the time it requires to Digivolve. The Care Items are stored away on the bottom-right side of the screen. Tap the panel to display the Care Items you currently own. Drag and drop these items to your Digimon to raise their Bond.
Improving Bond and allowing time to pass (a different amount for each In-Training I Digimon) will eventually enable a Digimon to Digivolve.
In-Training I Digimon can only be given In-Training I Care Items. In-Training I Care Items can be found in Quests and on DigiWalk.

A special Incubator that can only be used by joining a DigiGuild. It functions the same way as a normal Incubator.
For more info, check the DigiGuild section.

Battles refer to the fights that occur on Quests. Tamers give commands to their Digimon in battle, fighting alongside them.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/battle_1[/img] The key to winning a battle lies in directing your Digimon to use their Skills with proper timing.

Battles in Digimon ReArise progress automatically.
The order of attacks is based on each character's Speed (SPD).
Skills are used in order from the highest total team SPD. In Auto mode, Digimon use Skills in random order, regardless of SPD.

- Rounds Rounds represent the overall time elapsed in battle. One round ends once every character has used a Normal Attack. The number of rounds is displayed at the top of the battle screen.
- Turns Turns indicate each character's action in battle. Turns affect the duration of skill effects, and once the number of turns listed in the skill's description has elapsed, the skill's effect will wear off. Therefore, depending on the order of turns, the timing for the skill effect wearing off is different. *Special Actions like Counters and Pursuits don't affect number of turns. *When affected by status abnormalities like Shock and Freeze, one turn will pass without performing a Normal Attack.

Refers to a Digimon that can participate in battle besides your team members. Select another Tamer's Partner Digimon as your backup before battle.
When your team drops to 4 or fewer members (or starts off with fewer than 4 members), your backup will join the battle.
If there's a battle you can't seem to win, choosing a strong backup is a solid tactic.

Skills are the abilities used by Digimon. Obtainable Skills vary by each Digimon. There are 4 types of Skills:
• Main Skills 　Abilities unique to a single Digimon. 　You, the Tamer, can use this whenever you want. • Sub Skills 　Another type of ability Digimon can use. 　You, the Tamer, can use this whenever you want. • Passive Skills 　Abilities that activate automatically at the beginning of Battle. 　These Skills can strengthen your team members, weaken the abilities of your enemies, 　and more • EX Skills 　Abilities unique to Supercharged Digimon. 　You, the Tamer, can use this whenever you want. These abilities can only be learned in the last stage of Digivolution.

Abilities unique to a single Digimon. These are mainly attack-type Skills, some of which inflict status abnormalities on opponents.
Using a Main Skill makes it unavailable for a set period of time (the Cooldown phase). Once Cooldown is over, you can use the Skill again.
Upgrading a Main Skill's Skill Level to make its ability or effect more powerful.

Digimon hatch from DigiEggs. As they evolve, their appearance and abilities change at each juncture of their life cycle. This is called Digivolution, which is divided into different Stages:
- DigiEgg - In-Training I - In-Training II - Rookie - Champion - Ultimate - Mega - Armor - Ultra
In Digimon ReArise, Digimon in all shapes and sizes can be encountered in different Stages, even Ultimate and Mega. You can check a Digimon's Stage by opening the Digimon Status screen and looking at their Digivolution Chain, under the Profile tab. (Tap and hold the Digimon icon to open the screen.)

Another type of ability Digimon can use. These come in a variety of forms, including attacks, status abnormalities, defensive skills, or recovery.
Like the Main Skill, using a Sub Skill makes it unavailable for a set period of time (the Cooldown phase). Once Cooldown is over, you can use the Skill again.
Upgrading a Sub Skill's Skill Level to make its ability or effect more powerful.

Abilities that activate automatically at the beginning of Battle. Passive Skills usually play a support role: boosting ATK or DEF, or even granting resistance to certain status abnormalities.
Unlike Main Skills, Sub Skills, and EX Skills, there is no Cooldown. Instead, its effect has a time limit for the effect, expiring after a set number of turns have passed. Some Passive Skills have a permanent effect. As each wave of enemies appears, the ability will reset and its time limit begins again.
You cannot upgrade Passive Skills, so their effects do not change over time.

Sometimes Digimon perform special actions in battle aside from Normal Attacks, Main Skills, Sub Skills, and EX Skills.
• Critical 　When a Normal Attack or Skill is performed, 　the Digimon has a chance of dealing 150% damage. • Pinpoint 　Targets the enemy with the lowest HP. • Counter 　When attacked, the Digimon has a chance of 　dealing a counterattack to the enemy. • Block 　When attacked, the Digimon has a chance of 　reducing the damage received. • Pursuit 　After performing a Normal Attack or an ATK-type Skill, 　the Digimon has a chance of dealing another attack.

The better your Digimon's Mood, the better the effects on your battle.
- Critical hit, block, pinpoint and counter rates are higher. - The gauge for your Special fills more quickly. - Gain more Bond in the Battle Results. - Potential special rewards added to the Battle Results (Mood Bonus).

Certain status abnormalities can make it difficult for Digimon to fight during a battle. There are several types of effects:
- Shock Shocking electricity prevents a Digimon from using regular attacks or skills for a set number of turns. - Paralysis Paralyzing vegetation prevents a Digimon from using regular attacks or skills for a set number of turns. - Freeze The Digimon will freeze in place, unable to use regular attacks or skills for a set number of turns. 　While frozen, the Digimon will not be affected by any action taken by ally or enemy besides being unfrozen. - Stun Confusion prevents Digimon from using regular attacks or skills for a set number of turns. - Sleep The Digimon falls asleep, preventing them from using Normal Attacks or Skills for a set number of turns.

Certain status abnormalities can make it difficult for Digimon to fight during a battle. There are several types of effects:
• Poison 　Poison causes Digimon to take damage 　over time. • Burn 　Burned Digimon take damage 　over time. • Error 　Corrupts a Digimon, making them take damage 　over time. • Skill Lock 　Locks Main, Sub, and EX Skills, 　preventing their use. • Blind 　Darkness obscures a Digimon's vision, 　preventing use of Normal Attacks or Counters 　and reducing the accuracy of skills.

Refers to Skills that improve certain stats for the user or their allies.
- XX Up Refers to Skills that improve certain stats or raise success rates for certain battle parameters. POW, TEC, DEF, Critical Rate and other parameters are affected.

Refers to skills with adverse effects on foes.
- XX Down Refers to skills that reduce certain stats or lower success rates for certain battle parameters. PWR, TEC, DEF, Critical Rate, HP Recovery, Status Abnormality Resistance and other parameters are affected.

(More information about skills not listed on this page is available by following the directions below. From the Pause screen during battle, tap the Battle Details button, and then tap the Effects button.)
Skills can induce not only status abnormalities, but also the following effects:
• Provoke 　Direct enemy attacks toward the user. • Shorten Buff 　Reduces the number of turns 　buffs affect enemies. • Fixed Damage 　A set amount of damage is dealt 　regardless of opponent's DEF. • Ignore Block 　Deals damage to enemies 　by ignoring their block. • Critical Damage Up 　Increases damage 　during critical hit. • Self-Regeneration 　Recovers a set amount of HP periodically. • Max HP Up 　Increases Digimon's Max HP. • Total ATK Power Up 　Increases Digimon's Attack Power. 　This effect can be stacked and 　will be accumulated to a set value. • Attack Evasion 　Evades enemy's attack. • Divine Speed 　Main Skill is available to use 　as soon as battle starts. 　*Activates only at the start of the battle. 　*If there are multiple Digimon with Divine Speed, 　　the team with the higher total SPD will have Divine Speed activated. • CT Boost (Cooldown Boost) 　Skill CT is shortened by a set amount. • Dragon's Power 　Accumulate power each time you attack. Increases damage when using a skill 　when power has been accumulated. • Upgrade Block 　Increases damage reduction 　when Blocking an enemy. • Critical Guard 　No critical damage is taken. • Damage Limit 　Reduces the amount of damage received by a set amount. • Shield 　Creates a shield that absorbs a set amount of damage 　received from an opponent. 　If the damage exceeds a certain amount, the shield will disappear. • Personality's Bane 　Increases damage against Digimon with certain Personalities. 　Certain Personalities will also be easier to target. 　　Brave/Super Brave's Bane 　　Calm/Super Calm's Bane 　　Deft/Super Deft's Bane 　　Tenacious/Super Tenacious's Bane 　　Devoted/Super Devoted's Bane 　*Not applicable to Specials. • Shield Pierce 　Deals damage to both enemies and their shield. • Counter Damage Up 　Increases the amount of damage dealt by a counter. • Damage Limit Pierce 　Deals damage that 　ignores Damage Limit. 　At the same time, Damage Limit count is reduced by one. • HP Absorb 　Absorbs HP based on damage dealt and opponent's remaining HP 　and recovers own HP. 　*Not applicable to Specials. 　*Deals damage by ignoring 　　Attack Evasion, Damage Limit, and Shield. • Multi-Attack 　Attacks multiple times. Targets will be chosen 　at random. 　*If Multi-Attack triggers a Counter, 　　only counters one of the 　　Multi-Attacked enemies. • Remove Buff 　Removes buffs on enemies. 　*Buffs will be removed regardless of number of turns left or their permanency. 　　Buffs that can be removed will depend on the Digimon 　　using the skill. 　　For more details, please refer to 　　the Digimon's Skill description. • Remove Debuff 　Removes debuffs on allies. 　*Debuffs will be removed regardless of number of turns left or their permanency. 　　Debuffs that can be removed will depend on the Digimon 　　using the skill. 　　For more details, please refer to 　　the Digimon's Skill description. • Auto Revive 　Activates after a Digimon is K.O.'d. Digimon will be revived with 　a set amount of HP. 　Auto Revive is a Buff Skill that can be affected by Remove Buff. • Fade 　Inflict Fade on opponents. 　Digimon will be covered in red aura when inflicted with Fade. 　Each time an action is taken, Fade effect will worsen. 　After a set number of actions are taken, 　a K.O. will occur, regardless of remaining HP. 　*Actions that cause Fade to progress include 　　Main Skill, Sub Skill, EX Skill, 　　Normal Attack, Counter, and Pursuit. • Cover 　Directs all enemy attacks towards the user. 　Takes all attacks, including skills that hit multiple targets. 　Reduces damage received by a set amount. 　(Attacks, Debuffs, Status Abnormalities, and Remove Buff will be concentrated on a single Digimon with Cover.) • SPCRITICAL 　Occasionally deals huge damage. 　*Increases in probability, damage, etc. 　　(due to skill effects, Plugins, etc.) will have no effect. 　*Critical Guard is not affected. • Inflict Random Status Abnormality 　Inflicts one random Status Abnormality. • Status Abnormality Bane 　Increases damage against Digimon 　with certain status abnormalities. 　Digimon with certain status abnormalities 　will also be easier to target. 　(Shock Bane, Paralysis Bane, Stun Bane, Sleep Bane, 　　Poison Bane, Burn Bane, Error Bane, 　　Skill Lock Bane, Blind Bane) 　*Not applicable to Specials. • Fury 　When your remaining health is below a certain amount, 　you will receive various Buffs. 　*It will activate only once per battle. 　*If K.O.'d and then revived, the activation counter will be reset. • X-Antibody 　This only comes into effect in the Underworld Dungeon. 　It increases the Stats of Digimon. 　When activated, a blue light will appear at the feet of the target Digimon, 　highlighting it. • Remove Evasion 　Ignore an enemy's Attack Evasion and deals damage 　while removing all Attack Evasion effects on the enemy. *Attack Evasion will be removed regardless of whether it is a permanent or turn-based effect. • Future Weaver 　Increases damage against Spirals that appear in the 　Season Two vs. Guardians Main Story and afterwards. 　(Not applicable to Specials.)

A special and powerful skill that Partner Digimon can use in battle. It is more powerful than the main skills and so they act as a trump card of sorts.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/battle_2[/img] Unlike other skills, Specials do not have a Cooldown time. Instead, the Special Gauge will be filled with Special Pt. as the battle progresses. When the Gauge is full, you can use the skill at any time by tapping on the Special button.
Also, you can set Specials to be automatically used by doing the following: Tap Pause button ⇒ Settings ⇒ Select ON for Automatic Specials in Auto Mode during battle.

Digimon have 4 different stats—HP, PWR/TEC, DEF, and SPD.
- HP: Hit points are the amount of health a Digimon has. Once a Digimon's HP reaches 0, it will no longer be able to fight. - PWR/TEC: Power and Technique represent a Digimon's offensive capabilities. The higher either value is, the more damage Digimon are able to deal. A Digimon's Personality determines which attack type they wield. - DEF: Defense indicates how much protection a Digimon has. The higher the value, the less damage it will receive. - SPD: Speed indicates how quick a Digimon is. The higher the value, the quicker it will attack in battle.
A Digimon's attack type corresponds to their Personality. Digimon types proficient in power (Brave, Deft, or Tenacious) are more compatible with PWR, whereas more technical types (Calm, Deft, or Devoted) are better suited to TEC.
Deft Digimon can use both PWR and TEC-attack types, letting you incorporate them in all kinds of strategies.
Attack type is a very important parameter, influencing skill effect targets and equippable Plugins.
Attacks are always either PWR or TEC types. Attack types may vary among Digimon that appear the same at first glance.

Your Team is a group of up to five Digimon who accompany you into battle. Teams can be adjusted each time you go on a Quest.
From the DigiTown, select Team and choose the Digimon that you want at your side. Teams can be changed on other screens as well.
When making a Team, only one Digimon with the same Digivolution Chain and Stage can be used at a time.

You can create custom Teams for any type of mission.
Quests: Register up to 3 Teams Clash Battle: Register 3 Team Battle Park: Register up to 3 Teams

Quests are opportunities to fight alongside Digimon. You can engage in Quests in the following locations:
- Story - Dimensional Vortexes - Clash Battles - Battle Park - Underworld
Locked Quest locations become available as you proceed through the Story.

Enjoy battles within the context of the game's overarching story.
Quests in the Main Story consume stamina to play.
The story is split into <color=#e75600>Acts</color> and <color=#e75600>Scenes</color>. There are various kinds of Scenes.
Each Scene lets you enjoy a battle, but some only progress the story, while others offer no story progression at all.
Obtain bit and Care Items to power up your Digimon while playing the Main Story.

The Battle Results screen displays your battle score based on <sprite=4>, and the rewards you earned in battle.
You gain Tamer EXP from battle, and the Digimon that participated in battle gain Bond Points.

Items that can be acquired in battles fall into three categories:
- Enemy Drops Items dropped by defeated enemies. - Mood Bonuses You can receive additional rewards from battle depending on the Mood of your Digimon team members. The higher their Mood, the higher the chance of receiving Mood bonuses. Mood bonuses are not guaranteed. - First Clear Bonuses Bonuses that can only be acquired the first time you clear a quest. These bonuses can only be obtained once.

<sprite=4>(Stars) can be earned by fulfilling certain conditions in battle.
You can earn up to three stars in each Scene, and the fulfillment conditions change for each battle.

Collecting all the <sprite=4> (stars) in an Act earns you a Completion Reward.
Each Act has its own rewards.

Dimensional Vortexes are limited-time Quests that change depending on the date or time. Challenging these Quests requires stamina. Reward types and amount depend on the difficulty.
Item types are set in the Dimensional Vortex, so use this opportunity to collect specific items you need.

There are four types of the Dimensional Vortexes, each with different kinds of rewards:
• bit Vortex 　Acquire bit. • Food Vortex 　Acquire Care Items. • Workout Vortex 　Acquire Training Items. • Plugin Vortex 　Acquire Plugins.

Personality represents a Digimon's innate character, which can be categorized into 5 types. In Digimon ReArise, Digimon of the same name may have different Personalities; these Digimon are treated as different entities.
- Brave Digimon with this Personality often have superior attack-type skills. They use PWR-type attacks. - Calm Digimon with this Personality often have superior attack-type skills. They use TEC-type attacks. - Deft Digimon with this Personality often have balanced stats. They can have either PWR-type or TEC-type attacks. - Tenacious Digimon with this Personality often have high defense. They use PWR-type attacks. - Devoted Digimon with this Personality often possess support or recovery skills. They use TEC-type attacks.
Even if Digimon of the same name have the same Personality, they are considered separate Digimon if they have different final Digivolutions.

Dimensional Vortexes appear like clockwork, making it possible to predict when and where they will become available.
Alternatively, Vortex Keys can be used to force open Dimensional Vortexes for a set time.

In Clash Battles, you work with other Tamers to defeat powerful enemies that appear without warning.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/clash_1[/img] You can only challenge one Clash Battle enemy at a time. Anyone who participated in the Clash Battles will receive rewards. Each Clash Battle is available for 3 hours. *DigiRubies can be used to challenge Clash Battles any number of times.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/clash_2[/img] Every time a Clash Battle enemy is defeated, it becomes stronger. As it gets stronger, the more difficult it is to defeat; however, the rewards become more extravagant. On the other hand, losing against a Clash Battle enemy causes the level to go down.
[img width=844 height=325]tutorial/clash_3[/img] If you have trouble defeating a Clash Battle on your own, try sending out a Support Request. You can view Support Requests in the News section.
- Clash Battle Search You can battle against enemies from previous Clash Battles. In the main screen for Clash Battles, tap the Clash Battle Search button to display a list of enemies. Stamina is consumed when using Search. Level is set for each enemy, and a First Time Clear Reward can be claimed each time you clear a level.

You can receive rewards for Clash Battles by meeting the following conditions:
- Spotter A reward for the player who discovered and participated in the Clash Battle.
- Supporter A reward for players who join a Clash Battle in response to a Support Request.
- Total Damage Dealt A reward for top 3 players who dealt the most damage in a successful Clash Battle.
*Be aware that rewards will not be received in the following cases: - If you find a Clash Battle but do not participate in it. - If you could not deal damage to the enemy. - If you quit the Clash Battle halfway.
*Receiving Rewards If you defeat the enemy during your attempt, you may claim your rewards after the battle. If the enemy is defeated on another player's attempt or the Clash Battle ends in failure, you can claim rewards by confirming the result of that battle on the Clash Battle menu's Ended tab.
Clash Battles are a great place to pick up DGV-Codes (items required for Digivolution) and CB Medals (trade currency used in the shop).
Clash Battles may be triggered after you win battles in Story or Dimensional Vortexes.

Battle Park is a place where players can battle with other players' teams. Use exclusive BP Stamina to join the Battle Park. BP Stamina will automatically recover over time.
The team that annihilates the opposing team first wins the battle. There is a time limit, and once the time is up, the team with the higher combined HP remaining wins the battle.
BP Pointscan be obtained after winning the battle. BP Points reset each Season and is divided into two types: Season BP Pointsand Total BP Points accumulated throughout the season. By accumulating BP Points, your rank and your rankings will go up. Furthermore, depending on your actions and the conditions at the time of the victory, Bonus BP Points may be awarded.
[Victory] • Victory: Points added upon victory. • Crushing Victory Bonus: Points added if no one on the team has been defeated. • Narrow Victory Bonus: Points added if only 1 member of the team has survived. • Maximum Damage Bonus: Points added when a member from the player's team has dealt the most damage during battle. • First Knockdown Bonus: Points added when a member from the player's team defeats the other team's member first.
[Defeat] • Defeat: In the event of a loss, you will lose points in the Master League, but no points will be decreased or added in the Normal League. • Close Match Bonus: Points added when 4 enemies are defeated. Points will not be added if 3 or less enemies are defeated. • Maximum Damage Bonus: Points added when a member from the player's team has dealt the most damage during battle. • First Knockdown Bonus: Points added when a member from the player's team defeats the other team's member first.
A condition that increases a Digimon's Stats (HP, PWR/TEC, DEF, SPD). A Boost effect will be activated during battle under certain conditions. Boosts come in the following types: • Personality Boost A Boost that will be applied to Digimon depending on their Personality. When Personality Boost has been activated, the Digimon's icon will be highlighted with a red frame. • Limited Boost A Boost that will be applied to specific Digimon. When Limited Boost has been activated, the specified Digimon's icon will display an arrow. The more arrows, the greater the effect.
*Personality Boost and Limited Boost effects can be stacked.
*Use DigiRubies to recover the maximum amount of BP Stamina. *Unlike in Quest Mode, Specials cannot be used in the Battle Park. *The maximum BP Point is 999999999.

Battle periods in the Battle Park are called Seasons. The time period and time remaining in a Season can be checked via the top screen of the Battle Park. The totaling period starts from the end of the current Season and lasts until the beginning of the next Season.
Once the Season is over, players will receive rewards corresponding to their Ranks and respective League Rankings. Please refer to Battle Park Ranks and Leagues for more information.
*Rankings are updated once every hour. "Season Information" on the Battle Achievement screen will be updated each Season.

When joining the Battle Park, a rank is assigned to the players. Players will start from the lowest rank - Rank J.
Ranks depend on the total BP Points. Players must win a Promotion Battle in order to increase their rank. Promotion Battles will begin by accumulating the BP Points decided for each rank. A rank will not drop once you are promoted.
There are 11 ranks in total, and the higher you go up on the list, the higher the rank. Rank S Rank A Rank B Rank C Rank D Rank E Rank F Rank G Rank H Rank I Rank J
There are two leagues in the Battle Park, and players will be divided into either the Master League or Normal League at the end of each Season. The Master League is where the top Rank S players battle, while the rest of the players are matched up against each other in the Normal League.
• Players will be placed in each league according to the ranking results at the end of the Season. Those who placed 1st to 200th place will remain in the Master League. Those who placed 201th place and lower in the Master League will be switched out with those who ranked in the top 300 in the Normal League. At Rank S, you can choose between possible candidates for battle. The BP Points you receive will increase or decrease depending on the strength of your opponents. In the Master League, your BP Points will be decreased as a penalty if you lose or quit.

Players can earn Season Rewards and extraordinary rewards by participating in the Battle Park.
• Rank Rewards: Rewards will be given out at the end of the season based on each player's rank. The higher the rank, the better the rewards. • Ranking Rewards: Rewards will be based on the rankings of all users. Rewards will vary depending on the league you are participating in. The more BP Points you accumulate, the higher the rank.
Rewards are given out every time a player gets a promotion.
Rewards can be earned based on the number of battles players participate in, and will be reset daily. BP Stamina will be used to participate in battles regardless of battle results.
*Season Rewards can be claimed when visiting the Battle Park screen the following season. *Players cannot claim season rewards unless they have participated in Battle Park. *In cases where multiple players have accumulated the same amount of points, the player who achieved that number first will be ranked higher. *The Claim Rewards screen cannot be accessed again once it is closed.

Underworld is a special area that appears in the Digital World. There are 2 areas in Underworld, and both require Stamina to proceed through.
- Underworld Abyss 　Dozens of continuous floors of underground battle areas.
- Underworld Dungeon Battle areas that change greatly each time you enter.
